contextId.information: "What kind of great person will this baby grow up to be?" It is also possible that this question was meant to be a statement of their surprise at what they had heard about the baby. AT: "What a great man this child will be!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What then will this child become?

contextId.information: This was an indirect rebuke because he had not gone with them on the way back home. AT: "you should not have done this!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: why have you treated us this way?

contextId.information: Jesus uses two questions to mildly rebuke his parents, and to begin to tell them that he had a purpose from his heavenly Father that they did not understand. AT: "You did not need to be concerned about me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why were you searching for me?

contextId.information: He was not really expecting them to answer. John was rebuking the people because they were asking him to baptize them so that God would not punish them, but they did not want to stop sinning. AT: "You cannot flee from God's wrath like this" or "You cannot escape from God's wrath just by being baptized" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who warned you ... coming?

contextId.information: This question could be written as a statement. AT: "What do you, Jesus of Nazareth, have to do with us!" or We have nothing to do with you, Jesus of Nazareth!" or "You have no right to bother us, Jesus of Nazareth!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What do we have to do with you, Jesus of Nazareth?

contextId.information: The people were expressing how amazed they were that Jesus had the authority to command demons to leave a person. This can be written as a statement. AT: "These are amazing words!" or "His words are amazing!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What kind of words are these?

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. AT: "You should not argue about this in your hearts" or "You should not doubt that I have the authority to forgive sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why are you questioning this in your hearts?

contextId.information: Jesus uses this question to connect his power to forgive with the miracle of healing that he is going to do. It can be stated in active form. AT: "It is easy to say, 'Your sins are forgiven,' but only God can cause this lame man to 'Get up and walk'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Which is easier to say ... walk?

contextId.information: The Pharisees and scribes asked this question to express their disapproval that Jesus' disciples were eating with sinners. AT: "You should not eat with sinners!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you eat ... sinful people?

contextId.information: Jesus used this question to cause the people to think about a situation that they already know. This can be written as a statement. AT: "No one tells the wedding attendants of the bridegroom to fast while he is still with them" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can anyone make ... with them?

contextId.information: Jesus is rebuking the Pharisees for not learning from the scriptures. This can be written as a statement. AT: "You should learn from what you have read ... him" or "Certainly you have read ... him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you not even read ... him?

contextId.information: Jesus wanted to correct the Pharisees' understanding that it was wrong to heal on the Sabbath. He asked the question as a contrast between doing good and doing evil in order to make it obvious which one is lawful and which one is wrong. AT: "which action does God's law permitâ€”to do good and heal, or to do harm and destroy a life?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: is it lawful ... save a life ... destroy it?

contextId.information: "What reward will you receive?" or "What praise will you receive for doing that?" This can be written as a statement. AT: "You will not receive any reward for that" or "God will not reward you for that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: what credit is that to you?

contextId.information: Jesus used this question to get the people to think about something that they already know. This can be written as a statement. AT: "We all know that a blind person cannot guide another blind person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can a blind person guide another blind person?

contextId.information: Jesus asks this question to challenge the people to pay attention to their own sins before they pay attention to another person's sins. AT: "You should not say ... eye" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How can you say ... eye?

contextId.information: This expects a negative answer. "Did you go out to see a reed shaken by the wind? Of course not!" It can also be written as a statement. AT: "Surely you did not go out to see a reed being shaken by the wind!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What ... A reed shaken by the wind?

contextId.information: This also expects a negative answer, since John wore rough garments. "Did you go out to see a man dressed in soft clothes? Of course not!" This can also be written as a statement. AT: You certainly did not go out to see a man dressed in soft clothes!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But what ... A man dressed in soft clothes?

contextId.information: This leads to a positive answer. "Did you go out to see a prophet? Of course you did!" This can also be written as a statement. AT: "But you actually went out to see a prophet!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But what ... A prophet?

contextId.information: Jesus used these questions to introduce a comparison. They can be written as a statement. AT: "This is what I compare this generation to, and what they are like" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: To what, then, can I compare ... they like?

contextId.information: Jesus was rebuking them mildly because they did not trust him to take care of them. This can be written as a statement. AT: "You should have had faith" or "You should have trusted me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Where is your faith?

contextId.information: The implied answer to this question is that tit is not good. AT: "It will not benefit someone at all to gain the whole world, and yet lose himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What good is it ... forfeit himself?

contextId.information: Jesus is not seeking information. He uses these questions to test the Jewish teacher's knowledge. AT: "Tell me what Moses wrote in the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What is written in the law? How do you read it?

contextId.information: Jesus used a question to teach the disciples. AT: "Suppose one of you has" or "Suppose you have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Which of you will have

contextId.information: Jesus uses questions to teach his disciples. It could also be written as a statement. AT: "None of you fathers ... a fish" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Which father among you ... a fish?

contextId.information: "how much more certain is it that your Father in heaven will give the Holy Spirit ... him?" Jesus again uses a question to teach his disciples. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "you can be sure that your Father from heaven will give the Holy Spirit ... him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how much more will your Father from heaven give the Holy Spirit ... him?

contextId.information: "If I ... by whose power do your followers force demons to leave people?" Jesus uses a question to teach the people. The meaning of Jesus' question can be made explicit. AT: "If I ... then we must agree that your followers also drive out demons by Beelzebul's power. But you do not believe that it is true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: If I ... by whom do your followers drive them out

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to rebuke the Pharisees for not understanding that what is in their hearts matters to God. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "The one who made the outside also made the inside!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did not the one who made the outside also make the inside?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to teach the disciples. AT: "You know that five sparrows are sold for only two small coins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are not five sparrows sold for two small coins?

contextId.information: This question reflects what the man was thinking to himself. AT: "I do not know what to do, because I do not have any place big enough to store all my crops!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What will I do, because I do not have a place to store my crops?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to answer Peter's question indirectly. He expected those who wanted to be faithful managers to understand that the parable was about them. AT: "I said it for everyone who is ... right time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who then is ... right time?

contextId.information: People expected the Messiah to bring them peace from their enemies. Jesus is not going to do that now. AT: "You should not think that I have come to bring peace on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you think that I came to bring peace on the earth?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to rebuke the crowd. Jesus uses this question to convict them. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "you should know how to interpret the present time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how is it that you do not know how to interpret the present time?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to rebuke the crowd. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You yourselves should discern what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you not judge what is right for yourselves

contextId.information: "Were these Galileans more sinful ... way?" or "Does this prove that these Galileans were more sinful ... way?" Jesus uses this question to challenge the understanding of the people. AT: "You think that these Galileans were more sinful ... way" or "Do not think that these Galileans were more sinful ... way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you think that these Galileans were more sinful ... way?

contextId.information: "does this prove that they were more sinful ... Jerusalem?" Jesus uses this question to challenge the understanding of the people. AT: "do not think that they were more sinful ... Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: do you think they were worse sinners ... Jerusalem?

contextId.information: The man uses a question to emphasize that the tree is useless and the gardener should cut it down. AT: "Do not let it waste the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why let it waste the ground?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to convict the synagogue rulers. Jesus speaks about the women's disease as if it were ropes that bound her. This can be translated as an active statement. AT: "it is right to release her from the bonds of this illness ... day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: should her bonds not be untied ... day?

contextId.information: Jesus uses two questions to introduce what he is about to teach. AT: "I will tell you what the kingdom of God is like ... what I can compare it to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What is the kingdom of God like ... what can I compare it to?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question because he wanted them to admit that they would help their son or ox, even on the Sabbath. Therefore, it was right for him to heal people even on the Sabbath. AT: "If one of you has a son or an ox ... you would surely pull him out immediately" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Which of you who has a son or an ox ... will not immediately pull him out?

contextId.information: Jesus uses this question to prove that people count the cost of a project before they begin it. AT: "If a person wanted to build a tower, he would certainly first sit down and determine if he had enough money to complete it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: For which of you, who desires to build a tower, does not first sit down and count the cost to calculate if he has what he needs to complete it?

contextId.information: Jesus uses another question to teach the crowd about counting the cost. AT: "you know that a king ... would sit down first and take counsel ... men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: what king ... will not sit down first and take advice ... men?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to remind the people that if any of them lost one of their sheep, they would certainly go looking for it. AT: "Each of you ... would certainly leave ... until he finds it." Some languages have ways of showing that this is a hypothetical situation and not a story about a particular person who has lost a sheep. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: Which one of you ... will not leave ... until he finds it?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to remind the people that if any of them lost a silver coin, they would certainly look for it diligently. AT: "Any woman ... would certainly light a lamp ... and seek diligently until she has found it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Or what woman ... would not light a lamp ... and seek diligently until she has found it?

contextId.information: The rich man uses a question to scold the manager. AT: "I have heard what you are doing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What is this that I hear about you?

contextId.information: The manager asks this question of himself, as a means of reviewing his options. AT: "I need to think about what I should do ... job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What should I do ... job?

contextId.information: Jesus asks his disciples a question to help them think about the role of a servant. This could be a statement. AT: "But any of you ... will not say to him ... sit down to eat'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But which of you ... will say to him ... sit down to eat'?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a second question explain how the disciples would actually treat a servant. This can be a statement. AT: "He will certainly say to him ... eat and drink'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will he not say to him ... eat and drink'?

contextId.information: Jesus uses this question to show how people treat servants. This can be a statement. AT: "He would not thank the servant ... commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: He does not thank the servant ... commanded, does he?

contextId.information: This is the first of three rhetorical questions. Jesus used them to show the people around him how surprised and disappointed he was that only one of the ten men came back to glorify God. AT: "Ten men were healed" or "God healed ten men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Were not the ten cleansed?

contextId.information: This can be a statement. AT: "No one but this foreigner came back to give glory to God" or "God healed ten men, yet only this foreigner came back to give glory to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Were there no others who returned to give glory to God, except this foreigner?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to teach the disciples. This can be a statement. AT: "God will also certainly ... night!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: will not God also bring ... night?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to teach the disciples. This can be a statement. AT: "He will certainly not delay long over them!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will he delay long over them?

contextId.information: The purpose of the parable is to encourage the disciples to keep believing and pray. However, the form of the question indicates that the expected answer is negative. AT: "he will find many on earth who do not believe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: will he indeed find faith on the earth?

contextId.information: It is possible that they were asking for an answer. But it is more likely that they used the question to emphasize their surprise at what Jesus said. AT: "Then no one can be saved from sin!" or in active form: "Then God will not save anyone!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Then who can be saved?

contextId.information: The nobleman uses a question to rebuke the wicked servant. AT: "you should have put my money ... interest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: why did you not put my money ... interest?

contextId.information: This question emphasizes the decision of the vineyard owner. AT: "Here is what I will do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What will I do?

contextId.information: Jesus used a question to get his listeners to pay attention to what the owner of the vineyard would do. AT: "So now, listen to what the lord of the vineyard will do to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What then will the lord of the vineyard do to them?

contextId.information: "Why do they say ... son?" Jesus uses a question to make the scribes think about who the Messiah is. AT: "Let's think about them saying ... son." or "I will talk about them saying ... son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How do they say ... son?

contextId.information: "so how can the Christ be David's son?" This can be a statement. AT: "this shows that the Christ is not merely David's descendant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: so how is he David's son?

contextId.information: "For who is more important ... serves?" Jesus uses this question to begin to explain to the apostles who is truly great. AT: "I want you to think about who is greater ... serves." ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: For who is greater ... serves?

contextId.information: Jesus uses another question to teach the disciples. AT: "Of course the one who sits at the table is more important than the servant!" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it not the one who sits at the table?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to help the apostles remember how well the people provided for them as they traveled. AT: "Remember that when ... you had everything you needed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: When ... did you lack anything?

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "I am surprised that you are sleeping now" or 2) "You should not be sleeping now!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why are you sleeping?

contextId.information: "Do you come out with swords and clubs because you think I am a robber?" Jesus uses this question to scold the Jewish leaders. AT: "You know that I am not a robber, yet you come out to me bringing swords and clubs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs?

contextId.information: They use a question for emphasis. AT: "We have no further need for witnesses!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do we still need a witness?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to help the crowd understand that people are doing bad things now in good times, so certainly they will do worse things in the bad times in the future. AT: "You can see that they are doing these bad things while the tree is green, so you can be sure that they will do worse things when the tree is dry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: For if they do these things while the tree is green, what will happen when it is dry?

contextId.information: The criminal uses a question to mock Jesus. AT: "You claim to be the Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are you not the Christ?

contextId.information: The criminal uses a question to scold the other criminal. AT: "You must have no fear of God, since you mock Jesus while you are hanging on a cross just like he is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not fear God, since you are under the same sentence?

contextId.information: The men use a question to mildly criticize the women for looking in a tomb for a living person. AT: "You are looking for a living person among dead people" or "You should not be looking for someone who is alive in a place where they bury dead people!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you seek the living among the dead?

contextId.information: Cleopas uses this question to show his surprise that this man appeared not to know about the things that had happened in Jerusalem. AT: "You must be the only person ... days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are you the only person ... days?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to comfort them. AT: "Do not be frightened" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why are you troubled?

contextId.information: Jesus uses a question to mildly rebuke them. Jesus was telling them not to doubt that he was alive. The word "heart" refers to their thinking. AT: "Do not doubt in your minds!" or "Stop doubting!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Why do questions arise in your heart?
